        Email display settings<h2>Email display settings</h2>

        There is a setting<a href="/hosting/settings">setting</a> to control how
        your email address appears on comments and issues that you post.<p>There is a <a href="/hosting/settings">setting</a> to control how
        your email address appears on comments and issues that you post.</p>

        Project members will always see your full email address.  By
        default, other users who visit the site will see an
        abbreviated version of your email address.<p>Project members will always see your full email address.  By
        default, other users who visit the site will see an
        abbreviated version of your email address.</p>

        If you do not wish your email address to be shared, there
        are other ways to get
        involved<a href="http://www.chromium.org/getting-involved">get
        involved</a> in the community.  To report a problem when using
        the Chrome browser, you may use the "Report an issue..."  item
        on the "Help" menu.<p>If you do not wish your email address to be shared, there
        are other ways to <a href="http://www.chromium.org/getting-involved">get
        involved</a> in the community.  To report a problem when using
        the Chrome browser, you may use the "Report an issue..."  item
        on the "Help" menu.</p>


        
          
      
        <slot></slot>
      <button>
        <slot></slot>
      </button>
    
            Got it
          <chops-button>
            Got it
          </chops-button>
        <div class="edit-actions">
          <chops-button>
            Got it
          </chops-button>
        </div>
      <chops-dialog id="privacyDialog" forced="">
        <h2>Email display settings</h2>

        <p>There is a <a href="/hosting/settings">setting</a> to control how
        your email address appears on comments and issues that you post.</p>

        <p>Project members will always see your full email address.  By
        default, other users who visit the site will see an
        abbreviated version of your email address.</p>

        <p>If you do not wish your email address to be shared, there
        are other ways to <a href="http://www.chromium.org/getting-involved">get
        involved</a> in the community.  To report a problem when using
        the Chrome browser, you may use the "Report an issue..."  item
        on the "Help" menu.</p>


        <div class="edit-actions">
          <chops-button>
            Got it
          </chops-button>
        </div>
      </chops-dialog>

      
      
        
          <slot></slot>
        <div class="dialog-content">
          <slot></slot>
        </div>
      <dialog class="dialog" role="dialog">
        <div class="dialog-content">
          <slot></slot>
        </div>
      </dialog>
    
        This site hosts public issues in public projects<h2>This site hosts public issues in public projects</h2>

        Unlike our internal issue tracker, this site makes most
        issues public, unless the issue is labeled with a Restrict-View-*
        label, such as Restrict-View-Google.<p>Unlike our internal issue tracker, this site makes most
        issues public, unless the issue is labeled with a Restrict-View-*
        label, such as Restrict-View-Google.</p>

        Components are not used for permissions.  And, regardless of
        restriction labels, the issue reporter, owner,
        and Cc'd users may always view the issue.<p>Components are not used for permissions.  And, regardless of
        restriction labels, the issue reporter, owner,
        and Cc'd users may always view the issue.</p>

        

        
          
      
        <slot></slot>
      <button>
        <slot></slot>
      </button>
    
            Got it
          <chops-button>
            Got it
          </chops-button>
        <div class="edit-actions">
          <chops-button>
            Got it
          </chops-button>
        </div>
      <chops-dialog id="corpModeDialog" forced="">
        <h2>This site hosts public issues in public projects</h2>

        <p>Unlike our internal issue tracker, this site makes most
        issues public, unless the issue is labeled with a Restrict-View-*
        label, such as Restrict-View-Google.</p>

        <p>Components are not used for permissions.  And, regardless of
        restriction labels, the issue reporter, owner,
        and Cc'd users may always view the issue.</p>

          <chops-button>
            Got it
          </chops-button>

        mr-issue-details {
          font-size: var(--chops-main-font-size);
          background-color: var(--chops-white);
          padding-bottom: 1em;
          display: flex;
          align-items: stretch;
          justify-content: flex-start;
          flex-direction: column;
          margin: 0;

          margin-top: 1em;

        }
        mr-edit-issue {
          margin-top: 40px;
        }

          Comment 13<a class="comment-link" href="?id=1274323#c13">Comment 13<!----></a>

          
        by
        
      <link href="https://fonts.googleapis.com/icon?family=Material+Icons" rel="stylesheet">
      schedule<i id="availability-icon" class="material-icons inline-icon ${user.last_visit_timestamp ? '': 'inline-icon-unseen'}" title="undefined" hidden="">schedule</i>

    <mr-user-link></mr-user-link>

    <chops-timestamp title="Mon, Dec 20, 2021, 4:53 PM EST"></chops-timestamp>

        <div>
          <a class="comment-link" href="?id=1274323#c13">Comment 13<!----></a>

          
        by
        <mr-user-link></mr-user-link>
        on
        <chops-timestamp title="Mon, Dec 20, 2021, 4:53 PM EST"></chops-timestamp>
        
          <span class="role-label">Project Member</span>
      
        </div>
        
      <div role="heading" class="comment-header" aria-level="2">
        <div>
          <a class="comment-link" href="?id=1274323#c13">Comment 13<!----></a>

          
        by
        <mr-user-link></mr-user-link>
        on
        <chops-timestamp title="Mon, Dec 20, 2021, 4:53 PM EST"></chops-timestamp>
        
          <span class="role-label">Project Member</span>
      
        </div>
        
      </div>
    
      
        
        
      
        I have made some progress debugging this.<span class="line"><!---->I have made some progress debugging this.<!----></span><br><br>I can reproduce on linux if I manually enable oop-canvas. This appears to be a path made from 4 cubics and very large magnitude control point coordinates, and a very large stroke width (33 million-ish).  After the identified "cause" CLs, the stroke path renderer no longer accepts the path as-is (removing them actually causes a stack-overflow in chopping, so this bug would have triggered the same issue that the fuzzer bugs that Jim mentioned in c11).  However, since it isn't accepted as-is, we use the CPU stroker to turn it into a filled path with about 10,000 verbs and very large bounds.  <span class="line"><!---->I can reproduce on linux if I manually enable oop-canvas. This appears to be a path made from 4 cubics and very large magnitude control point coordinates, and a very large stroke width (33 million-ish).  After the identified "cause" CLs, the stroke path renderer no longer accepts the path as-is (removing them actually causes a stack-overflow in chopping, so this bug would have triggered the same issue that the fuzzer bugs that Jim mentioned in c11).  However, since it isn't accepted as-is, we use the CPU stroker to turn it into a filled path with about 10,000 verbs and very large bounds.  <!----></span><br><br>This filled path is acceptable to the filled tessellation renderer in the same family of HW tessellating renderers, albeit that renderer "pre-chops" the path to meet the fixed tessellation requirements. This produces a path with about 40k verbs in it. With the current logic in renderer sub-selection, it estimates that the cpu work of triangulating the inner control points outweighs the gpu fragment work (possibly a bug because it uses the unclipped draw bounds, which are massively larger than the viewport's actual fragment work).  Using the inner triangulating path renderer + stenciling just the curves appears to lead to memory corruption in the flush state's arena, so that when it's reset it accesses an invalid destructor function pointer.<span class="line"><!---->This filled path is acceptable to the filled tessellation renderer in the same family of HW tessellating renderers, albeit that renderer "pre-chops" the path to meet the fixed tessellation requirements. This produces a path with about 40k verbs in it. With the current logic in renderer sub-selection, it estimates that the cpu work of triangulating the inner control points outweighs the gpu fragment work (possibly a bug because it uses the unclipped draw bounds, which are massively larger than the viewport's actual fragment work).  Using the inner triangulating path renderer + stenciling just the curves appears to lead to memory corruption in the flush state's arena, so that when it's reset it accesses an invalid destructor function pointer.<!----></span><br><br>Tweaking the sub-selection choice to stencil the entire path and not just its curves allows it to render successfully.  I believe there are several underlying issues:<span class="line"><!---->Tweaking the sub-selection choice to stencil the entire path and not just its curves allows it to render successfully.  I believe there are several underlying issues:<!----></span><br>1. The cpu work vs. gpu work function needs work -> should it be based on the clipped draw bounds? should gpu work also be based on the number of verbs?<span class="line"><!---->1. The cpu work vs. gpu work function needs work -&gt; should it be based on the clipped draw bounds? should gpu work also be based on the number of verbs?<!----></span><br>2. Is it the number of stencil curve ops that corrupts the arena?<span class="line"><!---->2. Is it the number of stencil curve ops that corrupts the arena?<!----></span><br>3. Or is it the triangulation of such a large path that corrupts the arena?<span class="line"><!---->3. Or is it the triangulation of such a large path that corrupts the arena?<!----></span><br><br>Regardless of #1, we should be able to choose the inner triangulating path renderer and not corrupt the flush state arena, that suggests a memory over-run somewhere. I'm going to try and investigate #2/3 a little bit, but worst case, given RBS we can disable the inner triangulation and just rely on the stencil+cover op to avoid this particular crash in the short term.<span class="line"><!---->Regardless of #1, we should be able to choose the inner triangulating path renderer and not corrupt the flush state arena, that suggests a memory over-run somewhere. I'm going to try and investigate #2/3 a little bit, but worst case, given RBS we can disable the inner triangulation and just rely on the stencil+cover op to avoid this particular crash in the short term.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>
        
          
        <div>
          
        </div>
      <div class="comment-body">
        <mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>
        <div>
          
        </div>
      </div>
    
      
    <mr-comment headinglevel="2" commenterismember=""></mr-comment>
      
      
      
        
          Comment 14<a class="comment-link" href="?id=1274323#c14">Comment 14<!----></a>

          
        by
        
      <link href="https://fonts.googleapis.com/icon?family=Material+Icons" rel="stylesheet">
      schedule<i id="availability-icon" class="material-icons inline-icon ${user.last_visit_timestamp ? '': 'inline-icon-unseen'}" title="undefined" hidden="">schedule</i>
      michaelludwig@google.com<a id="user-link" href="/u/321186641" title="michaelludwig@google.com"><!---->michaelludwig@google.com<!----></a>
      michaelludwig@google.com<span id="user-text" hidden=""><!---->michaelludwig@google.com<!----></span>
      <div id="availability-text" class="availability-notice" title="undefined" hidden=""><!----><!----></div>
    <mr-user-link></mr-user-link>
        on
        
      Wed, Dec 22, 2021, 4:38 PM EST
    <chops-timestamp title="Wed, Dec 22, 2021, 4:38 PM EST"></chops-timestamp>
        
          Project Member<span class="role-label">Project Member</span>
      
        <div>
          <a class="comment-link" href="?id=1274323#c14">Comment 14<!----></a>

          
        by
        <mr-user-link></mr-user-link>
        on
        <chops-timestamp title="Wed, Dec 22, 2021, 4:38 PM EST"></chops-timestamp>
        
          <span class="role-label">Project Member</span>
      
        </div>
        
      <div role="heading" class="comment-header" aria-level="2">
        <div>
          <a class="comment-link" href="?id=1274323#c14">Comment 14<!----></a>

          
        by
        <mr-user-link></mr-user-link>
        on
        <chops-timestamp title="Wed, Dec 22, 2021, 4:38 PM EST"></chops-timestamp>
        
          <span class="role-label">Project Member</span>
      
        </div>
        
      </div>
    
      
        
        
      
        Recording more investigation progress:<span class="line"><!---->Recording more investigation progress:<!----></span><br>1. Having the inner triangulator use its own arena separate from the flush state arena does not seem to have memory corruption<span class="line"><!---->1. Having the inner triangulator use its own arena separate from the flush state arena does not seem to have memory corruption<!----></span><br>2. Having the inner triangulator skip recording bread crumb triangles lets it complete without crashing<span class="line"><!---->2. Having the inner triangulator skip recording bread crumb triangles lets it complete without crashing<!----></span><br>3. Drawing the GPU tessellated hulls does not seem to affect the crash, it is coupled with the GrInnerTriangulator's use of the arena<span class="line"><!---->3. Drawing the GPU tessellated hulls does not seem to affect the crash, it is coupled with the GrInnerTriangulator's use of the arena<!----></span><br>4. The specific corruption is in a footer of an allocated object in the arena. The footers track per-allocation destructors, skip over POD, or form the linked list between blocks of byte arrays. Specifically, it stores a function pointer and that appears to be corrupted with a value that points to high address space. I confirmed that such an address was never written into the arena.<span class="line"><!---->4. The specific corruption is in a footer of an allocated object in the arena. The footers track per-allocation destructors, skip over POD, or form the linked list between blocks of byte arrays. Specifically, it stores a function pointer and that appears to be corrupted with a value that points to high address space. I confirmed that such an address was never written into the arena.<!----></span><br>5. Using manual ASAN poisoning has not uncovered where the corruption originated from, unfortunately. The SkArenaAlloc uses unaligned memory to pack the footers as tightly as possible, so simply marking and unmarking those ranges may not actually let asan detect failures. This is because asan uses 8-byte aligned shadow memory for tracking, so detectable poison ranges need to be 8 byte aligned.<span class="line"><!---->5. Using manual ASAN poisoning has not uncovered where the corruption originated from, unfortunately. The SkArenaAlloc uses unaligned memory to pack the footers as tightly as possible, so simply marking and unmarking those ranges may not actually let asan detect failures. This is because asan uses 8-byte aligned shadow memory for tracking, so detectable poison ranges need to be 8 byte aligned.<!----></span><br>    - Running the fuzz test case with this modification crashes as before.<span class="line"><!---->    - Running the fuzz test case with this modification crashes as before.<!----></span><br>6. Modifying SkArenaAlloc so that every allocation is at least 8 byte aligned and all footer data fits into 8 byte aligned region bypasses the corruption<span class="line"><!---->6. Modifying SkArenaAlloc so that every allocation is at least 8 byte aligned and all footer data fits into 8 byte aligned region bypasses the corruption<!----></span><br>    - Running the fuzz test case with this modification seems to avoid or hide the underlying issue so there's no crash at all.<span class="line"><!---->    - Running the fuzz test case with this modification seems to avoid or hide the underlying issue so there's no crash at all.<!----></span><br>7. The arena gets very large, up to about 10GB in total storage, but the largest blocks are still valid sizes (just over 4GB, such that their size/offsets/etc. fit into the uint32_t limits imposed by SkArenaAlloc so we don't seem to be running into overflow issues).<span class="line"><!---->7. The arena gets very large, up to about 10GB in total storage, but the largest blocks are still valid sizes (just over 4GB, such that their size/offsets/etc. fit into the uint32_t limits imposed by SkArenaAlloc so we don't seem to be running into overflow issues).<!----></span><br>8. The specific geometry of the path being processed is a pathological case for triggering self intersections, which leads to a huge number of "breadcrumb" triangles needing to be created by the GrInnerTriangulator. It's not obvious to me if it's an issue with the breadcrumb triangle list data type being stored in the arena, the quantity of breadcrumbs, or some other fluke.<span class="line"><!---->8. The specific geometry of the path being processed is a pathological case for triggering self intersections, which leads to a huge number of "breadcrumb" triangles needing to be created by the GrInnerTriangulator. It's not obvious to me if it's an issue with the breadcrumb triangle list data type being stored in the arena, the quantity of breadcrumbs, or some other fluke.<!----></span><br>9. The triangulator's code that deals with the self intersections makes reproducing this in Skia or ASAN directly somewhat tricky. On Windows debug builds, the collinear edge detection hits a stack overflow before it can resolve all the self intersections (there are 10s of thousands to do, which turns into a very deep stack...).  On linux debug builds, it can complete successfully in skia without crashing although it does consum 10GB of data (and no asserts were tripped). Switching to linux+asan for skia directly re-encounters the stack limit issue so we never get to the resetting of the arena that crashes in chrome.  It would seem that chrome's asan build has a higher stack limit than the skia asan build, so if we can figure out how to adjust that, maybe we can debug more easily.<span class="line"><!---->9. The triangulator's code that deals with the self intersections makes reproducing this in Skia or ASAN directly somewhat tricky. On Windows debug builds, the collinear edge detection hits a stack overflow before it can resolve all the self intersections (there are 10s of thousands to do, which turns into a very deep stack...).  On linux debug builds, it can complete successfully in skia without crashing although it does consum 10GB of data (and no asserts were tripped). Switching to linux+asan for skia directly re-encounters the stack limit issue so we never get to the resetting of the arena that crashes in chrome.  It would seem that chrome's asan build has a higher stack limit than the skia asan build, so if we can figure out how to adjust that, maybe we can debug more easily.<!----></span><br>   - that being said, this does repro in content_shell with --single-process and --in-process-gpu so it's not so far off something that be wired to a debugger easily.<span class="line"><!---->   - that being said, this does repro in content_shell with --single-process and --in-process-gpu so it's not so far off something that be wired to a debugger easily.<!----></span><br><br>At this point, I think I'm going to apply option #1 from c13 to avoid the pathological case for the triangulator and avoid the crash.<span class="line"><!---->At this point, I think I'm going to apply option #1 from c13 to avoid the pathological case for the triangulator and avoid the crash.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>
        
          
        <div>
          
        </div>
      <div class="comment-body">
        <mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

          Comment 15<a class="comment-link" href="?id=1274323#c15">Comment 15<!----></a>

          
        by

      schedule<i id="availability-icon" class="material-icons inline-icon ${user.last_visit_timestamp ? '': 'inline-icon-unseen'}" title="undefined" hidden="">schedule</i>
      michaelludwig@google.com<a id="user-link" href="/u/321186641" title="michaelludwig@google.com"><!---->michaelludwig@google.com<!----></a>
      michaelludwig@google.com<span id="user-text" hidden=""><!---->michaelludwig@google.com<!----></span>

          Project Member<span class="role-label">Project Member</span>
      
        <div>
          <a class="comment-link" href="?id=1274323#c15">Comment 15<!----></a>

          
        by
        <mr-user-link></mr-user-link>
        on
        <chops-timestamp title="Thu, Dec 23, 2021, 3:39 PM EST"></chops-timestamp>
        
          <span class="role-label">Project Member</span>
      
        </div>
        
      <div role="heading" class="comment-header" aria-level="2">
        <div>
          <a class="comment-link" href="?id=1274323#c15">Comment 15<!----></a>

          
        by
        <mr-user-link></mr-user-link>
        on
        <chops-timestamp title="Thu, Dec 23, 2021, 3:39 PM EST"></chops-timestamp>
        
          <span class="role-label">Project Member</span>
      
        </div>
        
      </div>
    
      
        
        
      
        I've been able to identify the cause, and it was an int overflow in the SkArenaAlloc:<span class="line"><!---->I've been able to identify the cause, and it was an int overflow in the SkArenaAlloc:<!----></span><br>1. The arena stores cleanup actions in unaligned footers after allocations that need it. These handle invoking destructors for non-POD types, as well as deleting the blocks of arena data as well.<span class="line"><!---->1. The arena stores cleanup actions in unaligned footers after allocations that need it. These handle invoking destructors for non-POD types, as well as deleting the blocks of arena data as well.<!----></span><br>2. Starting with the last recorded footer location, each previous footer location can be reconstructed based on its associated allocation size.<span class="line"><!---->2. Starting with the last recorded footer location, each previous footer location can be reconstructed based on its associated allocation size.<!----></span><br>3. There is a special "skip" footer that is recorded when switching from a POD allocation to a non-POD allocation, since POD types do not have any footer at all.<span class="line"><!---->3. There is a special "skip" footer that is recorded when switching from a POD allocation to a non-POD allocation, since POD types do not have any footer at all.<!----></span><br>4. This skip is recorded as a uint32_t offset from the current cursor in the arena to the previous real footer so that the implicit linked list of footer locations is maintained.<span class="line"><!---->4. This skip is recorded as a uint32_t offset from the current cursor in the arena to the previous real footer so that the implicit linked list of footer locations is maintained.<!----></span><br>5. I hacked up SkArenaAlloc to also explicitly store all footer locations and detect if the data was corrupted after allocations, which it was not. I was also able to compare the expected sequence of footer locations from the explicit list and implicit embedded list during the destructor of the arena, and that identified an inconsistency.<span class="line"><!---->5. I hacked up SkArenaAlloc to also explicitly store all footer locations and detect if the data was corrupted after allocations, which it was not. I was also able to compare the expected sequence of footer locations from the explicit list and implicit embedded list during the destructor of the arena, and that identified an inconsistency.<!----></span><br>6. Because the inner triangulator required a substantial amount of breadcrumb triangles, which were POD types, the arena ended up allocating greater than int32::max of POD. Since this was recorded in the flush state arena, subsequent ops and programs were allocated as well, but these were nonPOD so a skip had to be recorded with a value greater than int32::max.<span class="line"><!---->6. Because the inner triangulator required a substantial amount of breadcrumb triangles, which were POD types, the arena ended up allocating greater than int32::max of POD. Since this was recorded in the flush state arena, subsequent ops and programs were allocated as well, but these were nonPOD so a skip had to be recorded with a value greater than int32::max.<!----></span><br>7. The skip is written as uint32_t, but in the SkipPOD footer action it was being read back into a plain int32_t and then overflowed. This caused the next footer location to be at a completely wrong address, meaning the footer action function pointer that it read was entirely arbitrary (ending up being something with high bits and trapped by ASAN).<span class="line"><!---->7. The skip is written as uint32_t, but in the SkipPOD footer action it was being read back into a plain int32_t and then overflowed. This caused the next footer location to be at a completely wrong address, meaning the footer action function pointer that it read was entirely arbitrary (ending up being something with high bits and trapped by ASAN).<!----></span><br><br>On the one hand, this is serious, since it leads to invoking a function pointer read from incorrect memory location. On the other hand, it's only encountered if the arena allocates POD > 2gb in a row, followed by non-POD data.  The regular triangulating path renderer and the inner triangulating variant of the tessellation path renderer are the most capable of this, since they can consume lots of memory when analyzing pathological paths, but in practice, those paths will likely cause OOM, stack overflow, or the triangulator will detect an edge explosion and just stop.  Given that, I think it'd be pretty difficult to apply on a non-ASAN build, certainly was the case when debugging at least...<span class="line"><!---->On the one hand, this is serious, since it leads to invoking a function pointer read from incorrect memory location. On the other hand, it's only encountered if the arena allocates POD &gt; 2gb in a row, followed by non-POD data.  The regular triangulating path renderer and the inner triangulating variant of the tessellation path renderer are the most capable of this, since they can consume lots of memory when analyzing pathological paths, but in practice, those paths will likely cause OOM, stack overflow, or the triangulator will detect an edge explosion and just stop.  Given that, I think it'd be pretty difficult to apply on a non-ASAN build, certainly was the case when debugging at least...<!----></span><br><br>The fix for the arena is here: <span class="line"><!---->The fix for the arena is here: <!----></span>https://skia-review.googlesource.com/c/skia/+/488527<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://skia-review.googlesource.com/c/skia/+/488527"><!---->https://skia-review.googlesource.com/c/skia/+/488527<!----></a> and I confirmed that it renders successfully without crashing. While that fixes the crash, it does still lead to a canvas2d draw operation requiring multiple gigs of ram to render, so <span class="line"><!----> and I confirmed that it renders successfully without crashing. While that fixes the crash, it does still lead to a canvas2d draw operation requiring multiple gigs of ram to render, so <!----></span>https://skia-review.googlesource.com/c/skia/+/488528<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://skia-review.googlesource.com/c/skia/+/488528"><!---->https://skia-review.googlesource.com/c/skia/+/488528<!----></a> adds the heuristic change to the tessellating path renderer to use the non-triangulating variant that is much faster for this path case.<span class="line"><!----> adds the heuristic change to the tessellating path renderer to use the non-triangulating variant that is much faster for this path case.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        by

        Going back to the scenarios from c14 and the results of c15, the reason that using a separate arena to store the triangulator's vertices and breadcrumbs never crashed was because it ended up only storing POD. Even though the recorded POD data would have been sufficiently large to create a bad skip footer, there were no subsequent non-POD allocations to trigger that. The non-POD allocations all remained in the flush state arena, which never had that degree of POD data allocated in one block.<span class="line"><!---->Going back to the scenarios from c14 and the results of c15, the reason that using a separate arena to store the triangulator's vertices and breadcrumbs never crashed was because it ended up only storing POD. Even though the recorded POD data would have been sufficiently large to create a bad skip footer, there were no subsequent non-POD allocations to trigger that. The non-POD allocations all remained in the flush state arena, which never had that degree of POD data allocated in one block.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        </div>

        *** Boilerplate reminders! ***<span class="line"><!---->*** Boilerplate reminders! ***<!----></span><br>Please do NOT publicly disclose details until a fix has been released to all our users. Early public disclosure may cancel the provisional reward. Also, please be considerate about disclosure when the bug affects a core library that may be used by other products. Please do NOT share this information with third parties who are not directly involved in fixing the bug. Doing so may cancel the provisional reward. Please be honest if you have already disclosed anything publicly or to third parties. Lastly, we understand that some of you are not interested in money. We offer the option to donate your reward to an eligible charity. If you prefer this option, let us know and we will also match your donation - subject to our discretion. Any rewards that are unclaimed after 12 months will be donated to a charity of our choosing.<span class="line"><!---->Please do NOT publicly disclose details until a fix has been released to all our users.         </div>
        
      </div>
    
      
        
        
      
        Congratulations! The VRP Panel has decided to award you $5000 for this report from your fuzzer + $1,000 fuzzer bonus. To prepare one, run:<!----></span><br><br>git clone <span class="line"><!---->git clone <!----></span>https://github.com/google/clusterfuzz<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://github.com/google/clusterfuzz"><!---->https://github.com/google/clusterfuzz<!----></a> && cd clusterfuzz && git checkout tags/reproduce-tool-stable<span class="line"><!----> &amp;&amp; cd clusterfuzz &amp;&amp; git checkout tags/reproduce-tool-stable<!----></span><br><br>To reproduce this issue, run:<span class="line"><!---->To reproduce this issue, run:<!----></span><br><br>./reproduce.sh -t <span class="line"><!---->./reproduce.sh -t <!----></span>https://clusterfuzz.com/testcase-detail/5684140533678080<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://clusterfuzz.com/testcase-detail/5684140533678080"><!---->https://clusterfuzz.com/testcase-detail/5684140533678080<!----></a> -b /path/to/build<span class="line"><!----> -b /path/to/build<!----></span><br><br>Please use the GN arguments provided in this report when building the binary.           Comment 13<a class="comment-link" href="?id=1274323#c13">Comment 13<!----></a>

          
        by
        
      <link href="https://fonts.googleapis.com/icon?family=Material+Icons" rel="stylesheet">
      schedule<i id="availability-icon" class="material-icons inline-icon ${user.last_visit_timestamp ? '': 'inline-icon-unseen'}" title="undefined" hidden="">schedule</i>

      michaelludwig@google.com<span id="user-text" hidden=""><!---->michaelludwig@google.com<!----></span>

          Project Member<span class="role-label">Project Member</span>
      
        <div>
          <a class="comment-link" href="?id=1274323#c13">Comment 13<!----></a>

          
        by
        <mr-user-link></mr-user-link>
        on
        <chops-timestamp title="Mon, Dec 20, 2021, 4:53 PM EST"></chops-timestamp>
        
          <span class="role-label">Project Member</span>
      
        </div>
        
      <div role="heading" class="comment-header" aria-level="2">
        <div>
          <a class="comment-link" href="?id=1274323#c13">Comment 13<!----></a>

          
        by
        <mr-user-link></mr-user-link>
        on
        <chops-timestamp title="Mon, Dec 20, 2021, 4:53 PM EST"></chops-timestamp>
        
          <span class="role-label">Project Member</span>
      
        </div>
        
      </div>
    
      
        
        
      
        I have made some progress debugging this.<span class="line"><!---->I have made some progress debugging this.<!----></span><br><br>I can reproduce on linux if I manually enable oop-canvas. This appears to be a path made from 4 cubics and very large magnitude control point coordinates, and a very large stroke width (33 million-ish).  After the identified "cause" CLs, the stroke path renderer no longer accepts the path as-is (removing them actually causes a stack-overflow in chopping, so this bug would have triggered the same issue that the fuzzer bugs that Jim mentioned in c11).  However, since it isn't accepted as-is, we use the CPU stroker to turn it into a filled path with about 10,000 verbs and very large bounds.  <span class="line"><!---->I can reproduce on linux if I manually enable oop-canvas. This appears to be a path made from 4 cubics and very large magnitude control point coordinates, and a very large stroke width (33 million-ish).  After the identified "cause" CLs, the stroke path renderer no longer accepts the path as-is (removing them actually causes a stack-overflow in chopping, so this bug would have triggered the same issue that the fuzzer bugs that Jim mentioned in c11).  However, since it isn't accepted as-is, we use the CPU stroker to turn it into a filled path with about 10,000 verbs and very large bounds.  <!----></span><br><br>This filled path is acceptable to the filled tessellation renderer in the same family of HW tessellating renderers, albeit that renderer "pre-chops" the path to meet the fixed tessellation requirements. This produces a path with about 40k verbs in it. With the current logic in renderer sub-selection, it estimates that the cpu work of triangulating the inner control points outweighs the gpu fragment work (possibly a bug because it uses the unclipped draw bounds, which are massively larger than the viewport's actual fragment work).  Using the inner triangulating path renderer + stenciling just the curves appears to lead to memory corruption in the flush state's arena, so that when it's reset it accesses an invalid destructor function pointer.<span class="line"><!---->This filled path is acceptable to the filled tessellation renderer in the same family of HW tessellating renderers, albeit that renderer "pre-chops" the path to meet the fixed tessellation requirements. This produces a path with about 40k verbs in it. With the current logic in renderer sub-selection, it estimates that the cpu work of triangulating the inner control points outweighs the gpu fragment work (possibly a bug because it uses the unclipped draw bounds, which are massively larger than the viewport's actual fragment work).  Using the inner triangulating path renderer + stenciling just the curves appears to lead to memory corruption in the flush state's arena, so that when it's reset it accesses an invalid destructor function pointer.<!----></span><br><br>Tweaking the sub-selection choice to stencil the entire path and not just its curves allows it to render successfully.  I believe there are several underlying issues:<span class="line"><!---->Tweaking the sub-selection choice to stencil the entire path and not just its curves allows it to render successfully.  I believe there are several underlying issues:<!----></span><br>1. The cpu work vs. gpu work function needs work -> should it be based on the clipped draw bounds? should gpu work also be based on the number of verbs?<span class="line"><!---->1. The cpu work vs. gpu work function needs work -&gt; should it be based on the clipped draw bounds? should gpu work also be based on the number of verbs?<!----></span><br>2. Is it the number of stencil curve ops that corrupts the arena?<span class="line"><!---->2. Is it the number of stencil curve ops that corrupts the arena?<!----></span><br>3. Or is it the triangulation of such a large path that corrupts the arena?<span class="line"><!---->3. Or is it the triangulation of such a large path that corrupts the arena?<!----></span><br><br>Regardless of #1, we should be able to choose the inner triangulating path renderer and not corrupt the flush state arena, that suggests a memory over-run somewhere. I'm going to try and investigate #2/3 a little bit, but worst case, given RBS we can disable the inner triangulation and just rely on the stencil+cover op to avoid this particular crash in the short term.<span class="line"><!---->Regardless of #1, we should be able to choose the inner triangulating path renderer and not corrupt the flush state arena, that suggests a memory over-run somewhere. I'm going to try and investigate #2/3 a little bit, but worst case, given RBS we can disable the inner triangulation and just rely on the stencil+cover op to avoid this particular crash in the short term.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>
        
          
        <div>
          
        </div>
      <div class="comment-body">
        <mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>
        <div>
          
        </div>
      </div>
    
      
    <mr-comment headinglevel="2" commenterismember=""></mr-comment>
      
      
      
        
          Comment 14<a class="comment-link" href="?id=1274323#c14">Comment 14<!----></a>

          
        by
        
      <link href="https://fonts.googleapis.com/icon?family=Material+Icons" rel="stylesheet">
      schedule<i id="availability-icon" class="material-icons inline-icon ${user.last_visit_timestamp ? '': 'inline-icon-unseen'}" title="undefined" hidden="">schedule</i>
      michaelludwig@google.com<a id="user-link" href="/u/321186641" title="michaelludwig@google.com"><!---->michaelludwig@google.com<!----></a>
      michaelludwig@google.com<span id="user-text" hidden=""><!---->michaelludwig@google.com<!----></span>
      <div id="availability-text" class="availability-notice" title="undefined" hidden=""><!----><!----></div>
    <mr-user-link></mr-user-link>
        on
        
      Wed, Dec 22, 2021, 4:38 PM EST
    <chops-timestamp title="Wed, Dec 22, 2021, 4:38 PM EST"></chops-timestamp>
        
          Project Member<span class="role-label">Project Member</span>
      
        <div>
          <a class="comment-link" href="?id=1274323#c14">Comment 14<!----></a>

          
        by
        <mr-user-link></mr-user-link>
        on
        <chops-timestamp title="Wed, Dec 22, 2021, 4:38 PM EST"></chops-timestamp>
        
          <span class="role-label">Project Member</span>
      
        </div>
        
      <div role="heading" class="comment-header" aria-level="2">
        <div>
          <a class="comment-link" href="?id=1274323#c14">Comment 14<!----></a>

          
        by
        <mr-user-link></mr-user-link>
        on
        <chops-timestamp title="Wed, Dec 22, 2021, 4:38 PM EST"></chops-timestamp>
        
          <span class="role-label">Project Member</span>
      
        </div>
        
      </div>
    
      
        
        
      
        Recording more investigation progress:<span class="line"><!---->Recording more investigation progress:<!----></span><br>1. Having the inner triangulator use its own arena separate from the flush state arena does not seem to have memory corruption<span class="line"><!---->1. Having the inner triangulator use its own arena separate from the flush state arena does not seem to have memory corruption<!----></span><br>2. Having the inner triangulator skip recording bread crumb triangles lets it complete without crashing<span class="line"><!---->2. Having the inner triangulator skip recording bread crumb triangles lets it complete without crashing<!----></span><br>3. Drawing the GPU tessellated hulls does not seem to affect the crash, it is coupled with the GrInnerTriangulator's use of the arena<span class="line"><!---->3. Drawing the GPU tessellated hulls does not seem to affect the crash, it is coupled with the GrInnerTriangulator's use of the arena<!----></span><br>4. The specific corruption is in a footer of an allocated object in the arena. The footers track per-allocation destructors, skip over POD, or form the linked list between blocks of byte arrays. Specifically, it stores a function pointer and that appears to be corrupted with a value that points to high address space. I confirmed that such an address was never written into the arena.<span class="line"><!---->4. The specific corruption is in a footer of an allocated object in the arena. The footers track per-allocation destructors, skip over POD, or form the linked list between blocks of byte arrays. Specifically, it stores a function pointer and that appears to be corrupted with a value that points to high address space. I confirmed that such an address was never written into the arena.<!----></span><br>5. Using manual ASAN poisoning has not uncovered where the corruption originated from, unfortunately. The SkArenaAlloc uses unaligned memory to pack the footers as tightly as possible, so simply marking and unmarking those ranges may not actually let asan detect failures. This is because asan uses 8-byte aligned shadow memory for tracking, so detectable poison ranges need to be 8 byte aligned.<span class="line"><!---->5. Using manual ASAN poisoning has not uncovered where the corruption originated from, unfortunately. The SkArenaAlloc uses unaligned memory to pack the footers as tightly as possible, so simply marking and unmarking those ranges may not actually let asan detect failures. This is because asan uses 8-byte aligned shadow memory for tracking, so detectable poison ranges need to be 8 byte aligned.<!----></span><br>    - Running the fuzz test case with this modification crashes as before.<span class="line"><!---->    - Running the fuzz test case with this modification crashes as before.<!----></span><br>6. Modifying SkArenaAlloc so that every allocation is at least 8 byte aligned and all footer data fits into 8 byte aligned region bypasses the corruption<span class="line"><!---->6. Modifying SkArenaAlloc so that every allocation is at least 8 byte aligned and all footer data fits into 8 byte aligned region bypasses the corruption<!----></span><br>    - Running the fuzz test case with this modification seems to avoid or hide the underlying issue so there's no crash at all.<span class="line"><!---->    - Running the fuzz test case with this modification seems to avoid or hide the underlying issue so there's no crash at all.<!----></span><br>7. The arena gets very large, up to about 10GB in total storage, but the largest blocks are still valid sizes (just over 4GB, such that their size/offsets/etc. fit into the uint32_t limits imposed by SkArenaAlloc so we don't seem to be running into overflow issues).<span class="line"><!---->7. The arena gets very large, up to about 10GB in total storage, but the largest blocks are still valid sizes (just over 4GB, such that their size/offsets/etc. fit into the uint32_t limits imposed by SkArenaAlloc so we don't seem to be running into overflow issues).<!----></span><br>8. The specific geometry of the path being processed is a pathological case for triggering self intersections, which leads to a huge number of "breadcrumb" triangles needing to be created by the GrInnerTriangulator. It's not obvious to me if it's an issue with the breadcrumb triangle list data type being stored in the arena, the quantity of breadcrumbs, or some other fluke.<span class="line"><!---->8. The specific geometry of the path being processed is a pathological case for triggering self intersections, which leads to a huge number of "breadcrumb" triangles needing to be created by the GrInnerTriangulator. It's not obvious to me if it's an issue with the breadcrumb triangle list data type being stored in the arena, the quantity of breadcrumbs, or some other fluke.<!----></span><br>9. The triangulator's code that deals with the self intersections makes reproducing this in Skia or ASAN directly somewhat tricky. On Windows debug builds, the collinear edge detection hits a stack overflow before it can resolve all the self intersections (there are 10s of thousands to do, which turns into a very deep stack...).  On linux debug builds, it can complete successfully in skia without crashing although it does consum 10GB of data (and no asserts were tripped). Switching to linux+asan for skia directly re-encounters the stack limit issue so we never get to the resetting of the arena that crashes in chrome.  It would seem that chrome's asan build has a higher stack limit than the skia asan build, so if we can figure out how to adjust that, maybe we can debug more easily.<span class="line"><!---->9. The triangulator's code that deals with the self intersections makes reproducing this in Skia or ASAN directly somewhat tricky. On Windows debug builds, the collinear edge detection hits a stack overflow before it can resolve all the self intersections (there are 10s of thousands to do, which turns into a very deep stack...).  On linux debug builds, it can complete successfully in skia without crashing although it does consum 10GB of data (and no asserts were tripped). Switching to linux+asan for skia directly re-encounters the stack limit issue so we never get to the resetting of the arena that crashes in chrome.  It would seem that chrome's asan build has a higher stack limit than the skia asan build, so if we can figure out how to adjust that, maybe we can debug more easily.<!----></span><br>   - that being said, this does repro in content_shell with --single-process and --in-process-gpu so it's not so far off something that be wired to a debugger easily.<span class="line"><!---->   - that being said, this does repro in content_shell with --single-process and --in-process-gpu so it's not so far off something that be wired to a debugger easily.<!----></span><br><br>At this point, I think I'm going to apply option #1 from c13 to avoid the pathological case for the triangulator and avoid the crash.<span class="line"><!---->At this point, I think I'm going to apply option #1 from c13 to avoid the pathological case for the triangulator and avoid the crash.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>
        
          
        <div>
          
        </div>
      <div class="comment-body">
        <mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>
        <div>
          
        </div>
      </div>

          Comment 15<a class="comment-link" href="?id=1274323#c15">Comment 15<!----></a>

          
        by
        
      <link href="https://fonts.googleapis.com/icon?family=Material+Icons" rel="stylesheet">
      schedule<i id="availability-icon" class="material-icons inline-icon ${user.last_visit_timestamp ? '': 'inline-icon-unseen'}" title="undefined" hidden="">schedule</i>
      michaelludwig@google.com<a id="user-link" href="/u/321186641" title="michaelludwig@google.com"><!---->michaelludwig@google.com<!----></a>
      michaelludwig@google.com<span id="user-text" hidden=""><!---->michaelludwig@google.com<!----></span>
      <div id="availability-text" class="availability-notice" title="undefined" hidden=""><!----><!----></div>
    <mr-user-link></mr-user-link>

    <chops-timestamp title="Thu, Dec 23, 2021, 3:39 PM EST"></chops-timestamp>
        
          Project Member<span class="role-label">Project Member</span>
      
        <div>
          <a class="comment-link" href="?id=1274323#c15">Comment 15<!----></a>

          
        by
        <mr-user-link></mr-user-link>
        on
        <chops-timestamp title="Thu, Dec 23, 2021, 3:39 PM EST"></chops-timestamp>
        
          <span class="role-label">Project Member</span>
      
        </div>
        
      <div role="heading" class="comment-header" aria-level="2">
        <div>
          <a class="comment-link" href="?id=1274323#c15">Comment 15<!----></a>

          
        by
        <mr-user-link></mr-user-link>
        on
        <chops-timestamp title="Thu, Dec 23, 2021, 3:39 PM EST"></chops-timestamp>
        
          <span class="role-label">Project Member</span>
      
        </div>
        
      </div>
    
      
        
        
      
        I've been able to identify the cause, and it was an int overflow in the SkArenaAlloc:<span class="line"><!---->I've been able to identify the cause, and it was an int overflow in the SkArenaAlloc:<!----></span><br>1. The arena stores cleanup actions in unaligned footers after allocations that need it. These handle invoking destructors for non-POD types, as well as deleting the blocks of arena data as well.<span class="line"><!---->1. The arena stores cleanup actions in unaligned footers after allocations that need it. These handle invoking destructors for non-POD types, as well as deleting the blocks of arena data as well.<!----></span><br>2. Starting with the last recorded footer location, each previous footer location can be reconstructed based on its associated allocation size.<span class="line"><!---->2. Starting with the last recorded footer location, each previous footer location can be reconstructed based on its associated allocation size.<!----></span><br>3. There is a special "skip" footer that is recorded when switching from a POD allocation to a non-POD allocation, since POD types do not have any footer at all.<span class="line"><!---->3. There is a special "skip" footer that is recorded when switching from a POD allocation to a non-POD allocation, since POD types do not have any footer at all.<!----></span><br>4. This skip is recorded as a uint32_t offset from the current cursor in the arena to the previous real footer so that the implicit linked list of footer locations is maintained.<span class="line"><!---->4. This skip is recorded as a uint32_t offset from the current cursor in the arena to the previous real footer so that the implicit linked list of footer locations is maintained.<!----></span><br>5. I hacked up SkArenaAlloc to also explicitly store all footer locations and detect if the data was corrupted after allocations, which it was not. I was also able to compare the expected sequence of footer locations from the explicit list and implicit embedded list during the destructor of the arena, and that identified an inconsistency.<span class="line"><!---->5. I hacked up SkArenaAlloc to also explicitly store all footer locations and detect if the data was corrupted after allocations, which it was not. I was also able to compare the expected sequence of footer locations from the explicit list and implicit embedded list during the destructor of the arena, and that identified an inconsistency.<!----></span><br>6. Because the inner triangulator required a substantial amount of breadcrumb triangles, which were POD types, the arena ended up allocating greater than int32::max of POD. Since this was recorded in the flush state arena, subsequent ops and programs were allocated as well, but these were nonPOD so a skip had to be recorded with a value greater than int32::max.<span class="line"><!---->6. Because the inner triangulator required a substantial amount of breadcrumb triangles, which were POD types, the arena ended up allocating greater than int32::max of POD. Since this was recorded in the flush state arena, subsequent ops and programs were allocated as well, but these were nonPOD so a skip had to be recorded with a value greater than int32::max.<!----></span><br>7. The skip is written as uint32_t, but in the SkipPOD footer action it was being read back into a plain int32_t and then overflowed. This caused the next footer location to be at a completely wrong address, meaning the footer action function pointer that it read was entirely arbitrary (ending up being something with high bits and trapped by ASAN).<span class="line"><!---->7. The skip is written as uint32_t, but in the SkipPOD footer action it was being read back into a plain int32_t and then overflowed. This caused the next footer location to be at a completely wrong address, meaning the footer action function pointer that it read was entirely arbitrary (ending up being something with high bits and trapped by ASAN).<!----></span><br><br>On the one hand, this is serious, since it leads to invoking a function pointer read from incorrect memory location. On the other hand, it's only encountered if the arena allocates POD > 2gb in a row, followed by non-POD data.  The regular triangulating path renderer and the inner triangulating variant of the tessellation path renderer are the most capable of this, since they can consume lots of memory when analyzing pathological paths, but in practice, those paths will likely cause OOM, stack overflow, or the triangulator will detect an edge explosion and just stop.  Given that, I think it'd be pretty difficult to apply on a non-ASAN build, certainly was the case when debugging at least...<span class="line"><!---->On the one hand, this is serious, since it leads to invoking a function pointer read from incorrect memory location. On the other hand, it's only encountered if the arena allocates POD &gt; 2gb in a row, followed by non-POD data.  The regular triangulating path renderer and the inner triangulating variant of the tessellation path renderer are the most capable of this, since they can consume lots of memory when analyzing pathological paths, but in practice, those paths will likely cause OOM, stack overflow, or the triangulator will detect an edge explosion and just stop.  Given that, I think it'd be pretty difficult to apply on a non-ASAN build, certainly was the case when debugging at least...<!----></span><br><br>The fix for the arena is here: <span class="line"><!---->The fix for the arena is here: <!----></span>https://skia-review.googlesource.com/c/skia/+/488527<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://skia-review.googlesource.com/c/skia/+/488527"><!---->https://skia-review.googlesource.com/c/skia/+/488527<!----></a> and I confirmed that it renders successfully without crashing. While that fixes the crash, it does still lead to a canvas2d draw operation requiring multiple gigs of ram to render, so <span class="line"><!----> and I confirmed that it renders successfully without crashing. While that fixes the crash, it does still lead to a canvas2d draw operation requiring multiple gigs of ram to render, so <!----></span>https://skia-review.googlesource.com/c/skia/+/488528<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://skia-review.googlesource.com/c/skia/+/488528"><!---->https://skia-review.googlesource.com/c/skia/+/488528<!----></a> adds the heuristic change to the tessellating path renderer to use the non-triangulating variant that is much faster for this path case.<span class="line"><!----> adds the heuristic change to the tessellating path renderer to use the non-triangulating variant that is much faster for this path case.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>
        
          
        <div>
          
        </div>

          <a class="comment-link" href="?id=1274323#c16">Comment 16<!----></a>

          
        by
        <mr-user-link></mr-user-link>
        on
        <chops-timestamp title="Thu, Dec 23, 2021, 3:42 PM EST"></chops-timestamp>
        
          <span class="role-label">Project Member</span>

        Going back to the scenarios from c14 and the results of c15, the reason that using a separate arena to store the triangulator's vertices and breadcrumbs never crashed was because it ended up only storing POD. Even though the recorded POD data would have been sufficiently large to create a bad skip footer, there were no subsequent non-POD allocations to trigger that. The non-POD allocations all remained in the flush state arena, which never had that degree of POD data allocated in one block.<span class="line"><!---->Going back to the scenarios from c14 and the results of c15, the reason that using a separate arena to store the triangulator's vertices and breadcrumbs never crashed was because it ended up only storing POD. Even though the recorded POD data would have been sufficiently large to create a bad skip footer, there were no subsequent non-POD allocations to trigger that. The non-POD allocations all remained in the flush state arena, which never had that degree of POD data allocated in one block.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>
        
          
        <div>
          
        </div>

        *** Boilerplate reminders! ***<span class="line"><!---->*** Boilerplate reminders! ***<!----></span><br>Please do NOT publicly disclose details until a fix has been released to all our users. Early public disclosure may cancel the provisional reward. Also, please be considerate about disclosure when the bug affects a core library that may be used by other products. Please do NOT share this information with third parties who are not directly involved in fixing the bug. Doing so may cancel the provisional reward. Please be honest if you have already disclosed anything publicly or to third parties. Lastly, we understand that some of you are not interested in money. We offer the option to donate your reward to an eligible charity. If you prefer this option, let us know and we will also match your donation - subject to our discretion. Any rewards that are unclaimed after 12 months will be donated to a charity of our choosing.<span class="line"><!---->Please do NOT publicly disclose details until a fix has been released to all our users. Early public disclosure may cancel the provisional reward. Also, please be considerate about disclosure when the bug affects a core library that may be used by other products. Please be honest if you have already disclosed anything publicly or to third parties. Lastly, we understand that some of you are not interested in money. We offer the option to donate your reward to an eligible charity. If you prefer this option, let us know and we will also match your donation - subject to our discretion. Any rewards that are unclaimed after 12 months will be donated to a charity of our choosing.<!----></span><br><br>Please contact <span class="line"><!---->Please contact <!----></span>security-vrp@chromium.org<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="mailto:security-vrp@chromium.org"><!---->security-vrp@chromium.org<!----></a> with any questions.<span class="line"><!----> with any questions.<!----></span><br>******************************<span class="line"><!---->******************************<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

If you have any feedback on reproducing test cases, let us know at <span class="line"><!---->Please use the GN arguments provided in this report when building the binary.           Comment 13<a class="comment-link" href="?id=1274323#c13">Comment 13<!----></a>

          
        by
        
      <link href="https://fonts.googleapis.com/icon?family=Material+Icons" rel="stylesheet">
      schedule<i id="availability-icon" class="material-icons inline-icon ${user.last_visit_timestamp ? '': 'inline-icon-unseen'}" title="undefined" hidden="">schedule</i>
      michaelludwig@google.com<a id="user-link" href="/u/321186641" title="michaelludwig@google.com"><!---->michaelludwig@google.com<!----></a>
      michaelludwig@google.com<span id="user-text" hidden=""><!---->michaelludwig@google.com<!----></span>
      <div id="availability-text" class="availability-notice" title="undefined" hidden=""><!----><!----></div>
    <mr-user-link></mr-user-link>
        on
        
      Mon, Dec 20, 2021, 4:53 PM EST
    <chops-timestamp title="Mon, Dec 20, 2021, 4:53 PM EST"></chops-timestamp>
        
          Project Member<span class="role-label">Project Member</span>
      
        <div>
          <a class="comment-link" href="?id=1274323#c13">Comment 13<!----></a>

          
        by
        <mr-user-link></mr-user-link>
        on
        <chops-timestamp title="Mon, Dec 20, 2021, 4:53 PM EST"></chops-timestamp>
        
          <span class="role-label">Project Member</span>
      
        </div>
        
      <div role="heading" class="comment-header" aria-level="2">
        <div>
          <a class="comment-link" href="?id=1274323#c13">Comment 13<!----></a>

          
        by
        <mr-user-link></mr-user-link>
        on
        <chops-timestamp title="Mon, Dec 20, 2021, 4:53 PM EST"></chops-timestamp>
        
          <span class="role-label">Project Member</span>
      
        </div>
        
      </div>
    
      
        
        
      
        I have made some progress debugging this.<span class="line"><!---->I have made some progress debugging this.<!----></span><br><br>I can reproduce on linux if I manually enable oop-canvas. This appears to be a path made from 4 cubics and very large magnitude control point coordinates, and a very large stroke width (33 million-ish).  After the identified "cause" CLs, the stroke path renderer no longer accepts the path as-is (removing them actually causes a stack-overflow in chopping, so this bug would have triggered the same issue that the fuzzer bugs that Jim mentioned in c11).  However, since it isn't accepted as-is, we use the CPU stroker to turn it into a filled path with about 10,000 verbs and very large bounds.  <span class="line"><!---->I can reproduce on linux if I manually enable oop-canvas. This appears to be a path made from 4 cubics and very large magnitude control point coordinates, and a very large stroke width (33 million-ish).  After the identified "cause" CLs, the stroke path renderer no longer accepts the path as-is (removing them actually causes a stack-overflow in chopping, so this bug would have triggered the same issue that the fuzzer bugs that Jim mentioned in c11).  However, since it isn't accepted as-is, we use the CPU stroker to turn it into a filled path with about 10,000 verbs and very large bounds.  <!----></span><br><br>This filled path is acceptable to the filled tessellation renderer in the same family of HW tessellating renderers, albeit that renderer "pre-chops" the path to meet the fixed tessellation requirements. This produces a path with about 40k verbs in it. With the current logic in renderer sub-selection, it estimates that the cpu work of triangulating the inner control points outweighs the gpu fragment work (possibly a bug because it uses the unclipped draw bounds, which are massively larger than the viewport's actual fragment work).  Using the inner triangulating path renderer + stenciling just the curves appears to lead to memory corruption in the flush state's arena, so that when it's reset it accesses an invalid destructor function pointer.<span class="line"><!---->This filled path is acceptable to the filled tessellation renderer in the same family of HW tessellating renderers, albeit that renderer "pre-chops" the path to meet the fixed tessellation requirements. This produces a path with about 40k verbs in it. With the current logic in renderer sub-selection, it estimates that the cpu work of triangulating the inner control points outweighs the gpu fragment work (possibly a bug because it uses the unclipped draw bounds, which are massively larger than the viewport's actual fragment work).  Using the inner triangulating path renderer + stenciling just the curves appears to lead to memory corruption in the flush state's arena, so that when it's reset it accesses an invalid destructor function pointer.<!----></span><br><br>Tweaking the sub-selection choice to stencil the entire path and not just its curves allows it to render successfully.  I believe there are several underlying issues:<span class="line"><!---->Tweaking the sub-selection choice to stencil the entire path and not just its curves allows it to render successfully.  I believe there are several underlying issues:<!----></span><br>1. The cpu work vs. gpu work function needs work -> should it be based on the clipped draw bounds? should gpu work also be based on the number of verbs?<span class="line"><!---->1. The cpu work vs. gpu work function needs work -&gt; should it be based on the clipped draw bounds? should gpu work also be based on the number of verbs?<!----></span><br>2. Is it the number of stencil curve ops that corrupts the arena?<span class="line"><!---->2. Is it the number of stencil curve ops that corrupts the arena?<!----></span><br>3. Or is it the triangulation of such a large path that corrupts the arena?<span class="line"><!---->3. Or is it the triangulation of such a large path that corrupts the arena?<!----></span><br><br>Regardless of #1, we should be able to choose the inner triangulating path renderer and not corrupt the flush state arena, that suggests a memory over-run somewhere. I'm going to try and investigate #2/3 a little bit, but worst case, given RBS we can disable the inner triangulation and just rely on the stencil+cover op to avoid this particular crash in the short term.<span class="line"><!---->Regardless of #1, we should be able to choose the inner triangulating path renderer and not corrupt the flush state arena, that suggests a memory over-run somewhere. I'm going to try and investigate #2/3 a little bit, but worst case, given RBS we can disable the inner triangulation and just rely on the stencil+cover op to avoid this particular crash in the short term.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>
        
          
        <div>
          
        </div>
      <div class="comment-body">
        <mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>
        <div>
          
        </div>
      </div>
    
      
    <mr-comment headinglevel="2" commenterismember=""></mr-comment>
      
      
      
        
          Comment 14<a class="comment-link" href="?id=1274323#c14">Comment 14<!----></a>

          
        by
        
      <link href="https://fonts.googleapis.com/icon?family=Material+Icons" rel="stylesheet">
      schedule<i id="availability-icon" class="material-icons inline-icon ${user.last_visit_timestamp ? '': 'inline-icon-unseen'}" title="undefined" hidden="">schedule</i>
      michaelludwig@google.com<a id="user-link" href="/u/321186641" title="michaelludwig@google.com"><!---->michaelludwig@google.com<!----></a>
      michaelludwig@google.com<span id="user-text" hidden=""><!---->michaelludwig@google.com<!----></span>
      <div id="availability-text" class="availability-notice" title="undefined" hidden=""><!----><!----></div>
    <mr-user-link></mr-user-link>
        on
        
      Wed, Dec 22, 2021, 4:38 PM EST
    <chops-timestamp title="Wed, Dec 22, 2021, 4:38 PM EST"></chops-timestamp>
        
          Project Member<span class="role-label">Project Member</span>
      
        <div>
          <a class="comment-link" href="?id=1274323#c14">Comment 14<!----></a>

          
        by
        <mr-user-link></mr-user-link>
        on
        <chops-timestamp title="Wed, Dec 22, 2021, 4:38 PM EST"></chops-timestamp>
        
          <span class="role-label">Project Member</span>
      
        </div>
        
      <div role="heading" class="comment-header" aria-level="2">
        <div>
          <a class="comment-link" href="?id=1274323#c14">Comment 14<!----></a>

          
        by
        <mr-user-link></mr-user-link>
        on
        <chops-timestamp title="Wed, Dec 22, 2021, 4:38 PM EST"></chops-timestamp>
        
          <span class="role-label">Project Member</span>
      
        </div>
        
      </div>
    
      
        
        
      
        Recording more investigation progress:<span class="line"><!---->Recording more investigation progress:<!----></span><br>1. Having the inner triangulator use its own arena separate from the flush state arena does not seem to have memory corruption<span class="line"><!---->1. Having the inner triangulator use its own arena separate from the flush state arena does not seem to have memory corruption<!----></span><br>2. Having the inner triangulator skip recording bread crumb triangles lets it complete without crashing<span class="line"><!---->2. Having the inner triangulator skip recording bread crumb triangles lets it complete without crashing<!----></span><br>3. Drawing the GPU tessellated hulls does not seem to affect the crash, it is coupled with the GrInnerTriangulator's use of the arena<span class="line"><!---->3. Drawing the GPU tessellated hulls does not seem to affect the crash, it is coupled with the GrInnerTriangulator's use of the arena<!----></span><br>4. The specific corruption is in a footer of an allocated object in the arena. The footers track per-allocation destructors, skip over POD, or form the linked list between blocks of byte arrays. Specifically, it stores a function pointer and that appears to be corrupted with a value that points to high address space. I confirmed that such an address was never written into the arena.<span class="line"><!---->4. The specific corruption is in a footer of an allocated object in the arena. The footers track per-allocation destructors, skip over POD, or form the linked list between blocks of byte arrays. Specifically, it stores a function pointer and that appears to be corrupted with a value that points to high address space. I confirmed that such an address was never written into the arena.<!----></span><br>5. Using manual ASAN poisoning has not uncovered where the corruption originated from, unfortunately. The SkArenaAlloc uses unaligned memory to pack the footers as tightly as possible, so simply marking and unmarking those ranges may not actually let asan detect failures. This is because asan uses 8-byte aligned shadow memory for tracking, so detectable poison ranges need to be 8 byte aligned.<span class="line"><!---->5. Using manual ASAN poisoning has not uncovered where the corruption originated from, unfortunately. The SkArenaAlloc uses unaligned memory to pack the footers as tightly as possible, so simply marking and unmarking those ranges may not actually let asan detect failures. This is because asan uses 8-byte aligned shadow memory for tracking, so detectable poison ranges need to be 8 byte aligned.<!----></span><br>    - Running the fuzz test case with this modification crashes as before.<span class="line"><!---->    - Running the fuzz test case with this modification crashes as before.<!----></span><br>6. Modifying SkArenaAlloc so that every allocation is at least 8 byte aligned and all footer data fits into 8 byte aligned region bypasses the corruption<span class="line"><!---->6. Modifying SkArenaAlloc so that every allocation is at least 8 byte aligned and all footer data fits into 8 byte aligned region bypasses the corruption<!----></span><br>    - Running the fuzz test case with this modification seems to avoid or hide the underlying issue so there's no crash at all.<span class="line"><!---->    - Running the fuzz test case with this modification seems to avoid or hide the underlying issue so there's no crash at all.<!----></span><br>7. The arena gets very large, up to about 10GB in total storage, but the largest blocks are still valid sizes (just over 4GB, such that their size/offsets/etc. fit into the uint32_t limits imposed by SkArenaAlloc so we don't seem to be running into overflow issues).<span class="line"><!---->7. The arena gets very large, up to about 10GB in total storage, but the largest blocks are still valid sizes (just over 4GB, such that their size/offsets/etc. fit into the uint32_t limits imposed by SkArenaAlloc so we don't seem to be running into overflow issues).<!----></span><br>8. The specific geometry of the path being processed is a pathological case for triggering self intersections, which leads to a huge number of "breadcrumb" triangles needing to be created by the GrInnerTriangulator. It's not obvious to me if it's an issue with the breadcrumb triangle list data type being stored in the arena, the quantity of breadcrumbs, or some other fluke.<span class="line"><!---->8. The specific geometry of the path being processed is a pathological case for triggering self intersections, which leads to a huge number of "breadcrumb" triangles needing to be created by the GrInnerTriangulator. It's not obvious to me if it's an issue with the breadcrumb triangle list data type being stored in the arena, the quantity of breadcrumbs, or some other fluke.<!----></span><br>9. The triangulator's code that deals with the self intersections makes reproducing this in Skia or ASAN directly somewhat tricky. On Windows debug builds, the collinear edge detection hits a stack overflow before it can resolve all the self intersections (there are 10s of thousands to do, which turns into a very deep stack...).  On linux debug builds, it can complete successfully in skia without crashing although it does consum 10GB of data (and no asserts were tripped). Switching to linux+asan for skia directly re-encounters the stack limit issue so we never get to the resetting of the arena that crashes in chrome.  It would seem that chrome's asan build has a higher stack limit than the skia asan build, so if we can figure out how to adjust that, maybe we can debug more easily.<span class="line"><!---->9. The triangulator's code that deals with the self intersections makes reproducing this in Skia or ASAN directly somewhat tricky. On Windows debug builds, the collinear edge detection hits a stack overflow before it can resolve all the self intersections (there are 10s of thousands to do, which turns into a very deep stack...).  On linux debug builds, it can complete successfully in skia without crashing although it does consum 10GB of data (and no asserts were tripped). Switching to linux+asan for skia directly re-encounters the stack limit issue so we never get to the resetting of the arena that crashes in chrome.  It would seem that chrome's asan build has a higher stack limit than the skia asan build, so if we can figure out how to adjust that, maybe we can debug more easily.<!----></span><br>   - that being said, this does repro in content_shell with --single-process and --in-process-gpu so it's not so far off something that be wired to a debugger easily.<span class="line"><!---->   - that being said, this does repro in content_shell with --single-process and --in-process-gpu so it's not so far off something that be wired to a debugger easily.<!----></span><br><br>At this point, I think I'm going to apply option #1 from c13 to avoid the pathological case for the triangulator and avoid the crash.<span class="line"><!---->At this point, I think I'm going to apply option #1 from c13 to avoid the pathological case for the triangulator and avoid the crash.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>
        
          
        <div>
          
        </div>
      <div class="comment-body">
        <mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>
        <div>
          
        </div>
      </div>
    
      
    <mr-comment headinglevel="2" commenterismember=""></mr-comment>
      
      
      
        
          Comment 15<a class="comment-link" href="?id=1274323#c15">Comment 15<!----></a>

          
        by
        
      <link href="https://fonts.googleapis.com/icon?family=Material+Icons" rel="stylesheet">
      schedule<i id="availability-icon" class="material-icons inline-icon ${user.last_visit_timestamp ? '': 'inline-icon-unseen'}" title="undefined" hidden="">schedule</i>

      michaelludwig@google.com<span id="user-text" hidden=""><!---->michaelludwig@google.com<!----></span>

        <div>
          <a class="comment-link" href="?id=1274323#c15">Comment 15<!----></a>

          
        by
        <mr-user-link></mr-user-link>
        on
        <chops-timestamp title="Thu, Dec 23, 2021, 3:39 PM EST"></chops-timestamp>
        
          <span class="role-label">Project Member</span>
